text:
- [Presenter] In this
video, you'll see how to use

AWS Cost Explorer with AWS
Elastic Disaster Recovery,
or AWS DRS.

With Cost Explorer, you can
gather cost and usage data
for the DRS service,
break down the monthly and daily costs,
and create a report to forecast the cost
and usage of the service.
To get started let's navigate to
AWS Elastic Disaster Recovery.

Notice that we currently
have 52 source servers

that are replicating and
being protected by DRS.

To help streamline the
process of estimating

and forecasting our DRS costs
we can tag our resources.

Let's go to settings to take
a look at our custom tags.

We can select edit to view the
default replication settings.
The settings include one custom tag
for the replication server.
If we wanted, we could create more.

For now we'll retain these
settings and move on.

Next, let's navigate to
Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud,

or Amazon EC2 to look at some
of the resources DRS is using.
Let's look at our running instances.

We have several AWS
Elastic Disaster Recovery
replication servers running.
Let's select one of them to view its tags.
This server has a tag named
AWS Elastic Disaster Recovery Managed.

This is one of the default tags
that we're going to leverage
in Cost Explorer.

Let's check another server to
see if it has the same tag.
As expected it does.

Next let's take a look at
the Elastic Block Store,
or EBS volumes.
We'll sort this list by name
in order to find the DRS resources.
Let's select a server and view its tags.
This resource also has

the AWS Elastic Disaster
Recovery Managed tag.
Let's check another one.
Here's the tag again.
Next let's view the EBS snapshots,

which are the third
resource we're looking for.

We'll select one of the
snapshots and view its tags.
This resource has also tagged
AWS Elastic Disaster Recovery Managed.

Next we'll make sure this
tag has been designated
as a cost allocation tag.
Let's navigate to billing.

In the list of user defined
cost allocation tags,

we can see the AWS Elastic
Disaster Recovery Managed tag.
It's already active,
but for the purposes of this example

let's go through the
process of activating it.
Note that it can take up to 24 hours
for a tag to become fully active.
Now let's navigate to AWS Cost Explorer
and take a look at the cost breakdowns.

Here we can see our last
six months of billing,
including DRS costs,

as well as costs for other
AWS services we're using.
We can select a bar on this graph

to see the cost for a
specific service that month.

For example, the DRS
cost for January, 2022
The DRS costs shown here
are only for the replication service.

If we want to include the
other resources DRS is using

we'll need to make use of
the cost allocation tag
we activated earlier.
Here's the tag.

Notice that we have two
tags to choose from here.

The one listed as no tag key
includes resources tagged

prior to the activation
of the cost allocation tag
and will not include detailed data.

For our purposes we'll look
at the resources tagged
after the activation of the tag.
Because we just activated the tag,
we can only see a point on the graph.

Let's narrow the date range
to better see the data.

We'll set the time range
to the last seven days.
Now we can see costs for two resources,
EC2 instances and EC2 other.
Let's group this by usage type.

Now we can see all the
different usage types
for these particular DRS resources.

Let's change this to a bar
graph to break it down more.
If we'd like to go even deeper,

we can switch the view
from monthly to daily.
Note that any resource DRS makes use of

will be tagged with a
relevant cost allocation tag
and the cost will show up here.
It's important to be aware of which region
you are filtering on

as well as your replication
server usage type
when interpreting the data.

Let's take a look at this
teal colored bar for June 4th
where we can see a total cost of $2.52.

This is for all the T3
small replication servers
we're using.
Next we'll look at the EBS snapshot costs.
For all 52 servers
there's essentially one volume for each,
which is only costing us 98 cents per day.

Finally, let's examine
the cost of the usage
of those EBS volumes.

As you can see, it's
costing us 76 cents per day.
Let's clear the grouping and tags.
Let's group by service.

We'll change the view
back from stack to bar.

Here we can see the
DRS costs for each day.
For June 2nd it's costing $34.94 per day
for the 52 servers that we're replicating.

This is made up of the hourly
rate per source server.

From this page, we can
also download the CSV
and export the file for reporting.

You've just seen how to
use AWS Cost Explorer
with AWS Elastic Disaster Recovery.
You can learn more about this topic

in the description and
links for this video.
Thanks for watching.
Now it's your turn to try.
